title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: pubbias functions conduct sensitivity analyses publication bias affirmative studies (.e., statistically significant estimates desired direction) likely published nonaffirmative studies (.e., nonsignificant estimates estimates undesired direction) certain ratio, called selection_ratio (Mathur & VanderWeele (2020)). provide intuition, suppose knew affirmative studies twice likely published nonaffirmative studies. correct meta-analytic estimate published nonaffirmative study contribute twice much weight analysis affirmative study, counteract publication process’ two-fold favoring affirmative studies. idea similar familiar procedures used correct survey samples nonrepresentative sampling. However, practice, know exactly severe publication bias . case, can instead conduct sensitivity analyses describe severity publication bias (.e., selection_ratio) required explain away results meta-analysis (e.g., shift point estimate null).

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: chosen ratio publication probabilities, selection_ratio, can estimate publication bias-corrected pooled point estimate confidence interval per Mathur & VanderWeele (2020). Model options include fixed-effects (.k.. “common-effect”), robust independent, robust clustered specifications. Since selection ratio 1 corresponds publication bias (.e., affirmative nonaffirmative studies equally likely published), passing selection_ratio = 1 recovers uncorrected point estimate obtained . consider publication bias, can choose value selection_ratio greater 1. example, consider publication bias affirmative results 4 times likely published nonaffirmative results. fixed-effects meta-analysis indicates affirmative (.e., significant positive) studies 4 times likely published nonaffirmative (.e., nonsignificant negative) studies, meta-analytic point estimate corrected publication bias 0.12 (95% CI [0.09, 0.15]). Now use selection ratio, use robust random-effects specification account heterogeneity clustering point estimates within papers (default behavior pubbias_meta()). random-effects meta-analysis indicates , affirmative (.e., significant positive) studies 4 times likely published nonaffirmative (.e., nonsignificant negative) studies, meta-analytic point estimate corrected publication bias 0.13 (95% CI [0.06, 0.2]). pubbias_meta number arguments can used change model publication bias. default, pubbias_meta assumes publication bias favors positive-signed, significant results, contexts publication bias might instead favor negative-signed, significant results (e.g., investigators wish show treatment protective effect detrimental outcome). cases, pass favor_positive = FALSE. Also, function default assumes publication bias considered one-tailed model publication bias significant results positive point estimates favored, significant results negative point estimates nonsignificant results equally disfavored. contexts, possible instead significant results favored regardless direction, nonsignificant results disfavored (called “two-tailed” selection). recommend default conducting sensitivity analyses assume one-tailed selection statistically conservative, can also assess two-tailed selection using argument selection_tails. Finally, function default assumes results treated significant α = 0.05. change threshold publication bias assumed operate, can use argument alpha_select.
code: pubbias_meat_1 <- pubbias_meta(meta_meat$yi,                                meta_meat$vi,                                model_type = "fixed",                                selection_ratio = 1) pubbias_meat_1$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   model   estimate     se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #>   <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 pubbias    0.200 0.0117    0.177    0.224       0 pubbias_meat_4 <- pubbias_meta(meta_meat$yi,                                meta_meat$vi,                                model_type = "fixed",                                selection_ratio = sr) pubbias_meat_4$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   model   estimate     se ci_lower ci_upper  p_value #>   <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl> #> 1 pubbias    0.120 0.0136   0.0931    0.147 4.13e-14 pubbias_meat_4 <- pubbias_meta(meta_meat$yi,                                meta_meat$vi,                                cluster = meta_meat$cluster,                                selection_ratio = 4) pubbias_meat_4$stats #>     model estimate    se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #> 1 pubbias     0.13 0.032    0.062      0.2 0.00079

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: limiting case, can conduct meta-analysis nonaffirmative results (MAN) accounts worst-case publication bias. , affirmative studies infinitely likely published nonaffirmative studies, obtain corrected estimate nonaffirmative studies contribute infinitely weight analysis affirmative studies. fact corresponds retaining nonaffirmative studies analysis. Unlike standard publication bias methods, MAN can help assess robustness forms selective reporting besides publication bias. particular, MAN accommodates situations investigators manipulate selectively report results within studies, called “p-hacking” (Mathur (2022)). worst-case publication bias (.e., favors affirmative results infinitely nonaffirmative results), corrected meta-analytic point estimate 0.09 (95% CI [0.03, 0.16]).
code: pubbias_meat_4 <- pubbias_meta(meta_meat$yi,                                meta_meat$vi,                                cluster = meta_meat$cluster,                                selection_ratio = 4,                                return_worst_meta = TRUE)  pubbias_meat_4$stats #>        model estimate    se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #> 1    pubbias    0.129 0.032    0.062     0.20 0.00079 #> 2 worst_case    0.093 0.030    0.029     0.16 0.00733

what: Publication bias required to explain away the results
title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: can also calculate S-value, defined severity publication bias (.e., ratio affirmative studies likely published nonaffirmative studies) required shift pooled point estimate confidence interval limit null, value q (defaults 0, null). results indicate , model publication bias, amount publication bias shift point estimate 0. fact, also amount publication bias shift CI bound 0. Now consider severity publication bias required shift point estimate CI bound q = 0.1 rather null. results indicate , point estimate corrected publication bias shift 0.1, affirmative studies need 23.19 times likely published nonaffirmative studies. Additionally, CI bound corrected publication bias shift 0.1, affirmative studies need 1.48 times likely published nonaffirmative studies. general, S-value small enough represents plausible amount publication bias (see empirical benchmarks provided (Mathur & VanderWeele (2019)), meta-analysis may considered relatively sensitive publication bias. contrast, S-value represents implausibly large amount publication bias, one might consider meta-analysis relatively robust. methods can sometimes indicate amount publication bias assumed model “explain away” results meta-analysis, providing compelling argument robustness.
code: svalue_meat_0 <- pubbias_svalue(meta_meat$yi,                                 meta_meat$vi,                                 cluster = meta_meat$cluster) svalue_meat_0$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   sval_est     sval_ci      #>   <chr>        <chr>        #> 1 Not possible Not possible svalue_meat_01 <- pubbias_svalue(meta_meat$yi,                                  meta_meat$vi,                                  cluster = meta_meat$cluster,                                  q = 0.1) svalue_meat_01$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   sval_est sval_ci #>      <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1     23.2    1.48

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: visual supplement proposed sensitivity analyses, suggest presenting modified funnel plot called “significance funnel plot”. plot distinguishes affirmative nonaffirmative studies, helping detect extent nonaffirmative studies’ point estimates systematically smaller entire set point estimates. estimate among nonaffirmative studies (gray diamond) represents corrected estimate worst-case publication bias. gray diamond represents negligible effect size much smaller pooled estimate among studies (black diamond), suggests meta-analysis may robust extreme publication bias. Numerical sensitivity analyses (via pubbias_svalue() pubbias_meta()) still carried precise quantitative conclusions.

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: Publication bias, assessed standard methods, corresponds selection process filters studies published available inclusion meta-analysis. However, can also selective reporting within studies. example, investigators may “p-hack” analyzing multiple outcomes reporting affirmative results among analyses, fitting multiple models dataset attempt obtain affirmative estimate. Standard methods publication bias can biased either direction p-hacking (Mathur (2022)). However, meta-analysis nonaffirmative results (MAN, described ) MAN still provides conservative estimate (.e., biased toward null) p-hacking favors affirmative results (Mathur (2022)). Additional sensitivity analyses joint publication bias p-hacking can conducted. Assuming published, hacked studies never nonaffirmative estimates (e.g., investigators p-hack obtain affirmative estimate), propose estimating underlying meta-analytic mean fitting “right-truncated meta-analysis” (RTMA) published nonaffirmative estimates, unhacked. Unlike packages, phacking package uses Stan fit models requires Stan RStan installed.

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: function phacking_meta() fits right-truncated meta-analysis (RTMA), bias correction joint effects p-hacking (.e., manipulation results within studies obtain significant, positive estimates) traditional publication bias (.e., selective publication studies significant, positive results) meta-analyses. results, mode, median, mean represent posterior modes, medians, means respectively. recommend reporting mode (Mathur (2022)). results indicate , accounting potential p-hacking publication bias favor affirmative results, estimated meta-analytic mean, mu, 0.21 estimated standard deviation effects (.e., heterogeneity), tau, 0.14.
code: phacking_meat <- phacking_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi, vi = meta_meat$vi, parallelize = FALSE) #>  #> SAMPLING FOR MODEL 'phacking_rtma' NOW (CHAIN 1). #> Chain 1:  #> Chain 1: Gradient evaluation took 0.000434 seconds #> Chain 1: 1000 transitions using 10 leapfrog steps per transition would take 4.34 seconds. #> Chain 1: Adjust your expectations accordingly! title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: assess fit right-truncated meta-analysis possible violations distributional assumptions, can plot fitted cumulative distribution function (CDF) published nonaffirmative estimates versus empirical CDF. points adhere fairly closely 45-degree line, right-truncated meta-analysis may fit adequately.  another diagnostic plot, can examine Z-scores published point estimates. p-hacking favors affirmative estimates nonaffirmative estimates, methods others assume, Z-scores may disproportionately concentrate just critical value (e.g., 1.96). Importantly, presence p-hacking guarantee concentration Z-scores just critical value, prudent proceed fitting RTMA even concentration apparent. contrast, Z-scores also concentrate just critical value, also concentrate sign-reversed critical value (e.g., –1.96), indicate forms p-hacking violate assumptions RTMA.

title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: addition publication bias /p-hacking, meta-analyses can compromised internal biases (e.g., confounding nonrandomized studies) well publication bias. biases often operate nonadditively: publication bias favors significant, positive results selects indirectly studies internal bias. sensitivity analyses address two questions: (1) “given severity internal bias across studies publication bias, much results change?”; (2) “given severity publication bias, severe internal bias , hypothetically, attenuate results null given amount?” methods consider average internal bias across studies, obviating specifying bias study individually. analyst can assume internal bias affects studies, alternatively known subset (e.g., nonrandomized studies). internal bias can unknown origin , certain types bias causal estimates, can bounded analytically. analyst can specify severity publication bias , alternatively, consider “worst-case” publication bias described . sensitivity analyses involve specifying selection ratio publication bias, mean additive internal bias among published, internally biased studies affirmative (bias_affirmative) nonaffirmative (bias_nonaffirmative). respectively. guidance choosing sensitivity parameters given Mathur (2022).

what: Correction for internal bias and/or publication bias
title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: assume studies internally biased (bias_affirmative = 0, bias_nonaffirmative = 0) publication bias (e.g., selection ratio = 4), results match pubbias_meta. results indicate affirmative studies 4 times likely published nonaffirmative studies studies internal bias, corrected meta-analytic point estimate 0.13 (95% CI [0.09, 0.17]). Following Mathur (2022), now consider publication bias affirmative studies 4 times likely published, also nonrandomized studies , average, biased due confounding. details specifying values latter sensitivity parameters, see Mathur (2022). results indicate (1) affirmative studies 4 times likely published nonaffirmative studies; (2) affirmative, nonrandomized studies mean internal bias log(1.5); (3) nonaffirmative, nonrandomized studies mean internal bias log(1.1), (4) randomized studies internal bias, corrected meta-analytic point estimate 0.13 (95% CI [0.09, 0.17]). can repeat sensitivity analysis, now treating studies internally biased (just nonrandomized studies).
code: multi_meat_0 <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                vi = meta_meat$vi,                                selection_ratio = 4,                                bias_affirmative = 0,                                bias_nonaffirmative = 0) multi_meat_0$stats #>       model estimate    se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #> 1 multibias     0.13 0.021    0.087     0.17 1.3e-07 multi_meat_1 <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                vi = meta_meat$vi,                                biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                                selection_ratio = 4,                                bias_affirmative = log(1.5),                                bias_nonaffirmative = log(1.1)) multi_meat_1$stats #>       model estimate    se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #> 1 multibias    0.095 0.024    0.047     0.14 0.00025 multi_meat_1 <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                vi = meta_meat$vi,                                biased = TRUE,                                selection_ratio = 4,                                bias_affirmative = log(1.5),                                bias_nonaffirmative = log(1.1)) multi_meat_1$stats #>       model estimate    se ci_lower ci_upper p_value #> 1 multibias     0.01 0.021   -0.032    0.052    0.63

what: Bias required to explain away the results
title: Metabias packages tutorial
text: can also calculate, given severity publication bias, severe average internal bias across studies , hypothetically, attenuate results null given amount. selection ratio 4 assuming nonrandomized studies internal bias: results indicate affirmative studies 4 likely get published nonaffirmative studies, point estimate corrected internal bias shift 0, non-randomized studies need average internal bias 0.54. CI bound corrected internal bias shift 0, non-randomized studies need average internal bias 0.27. Now consider shifting point estimate CI bound q = 0.1 rather null. far, worked sensitivity parameters, bias_affirmative bias_nonaffirmative, simply summarize additive internal bias across studies without making assumptions source. However, certain types bias estimates causal parameter (e.g., treatment effect), bias can reparameterized directly describe structural associations involve latent variables, uncontrolled confounders, responsible bias. reparameterizations apply studies’ unadjusted estimates log risk ratio scale approximately transformed scale via usual approaches meta-analysis. , sensitivity parameters regarding bias risk ratio (RR) scale can expressed terms structural associations involving latent variables. See Mathur (2022) details. example, uncontrolled confounding, bias RR scale can expressed terms minimum strength confounding associations need present average across studies order produce amount bias indicated bias_est bias_ci. given study, two relevant confounding associations defined : (1) RR uncontrolled confounder(s) associated exposure; (2) RR uncontrolled confounder(s) associated outcome. confounding associations conditional controlled covariates. results indicate affirmative studies 4 likely get published nonaffirmative studies, point estimate corrected internal bias shift 0, non-randomized studies need confounding associations 2.82. CI bound corrected internal bias shift 0.1, non-randomized studies need confounding associations 1.95. interpretation parameters, see Mathur (2022).
code: evalue_meat <- multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                 vi = meta_meat$vi,                                 biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                                 selection_ratio = 4) evalue_meat$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   bias_est bias_ci #>      <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1    0.539   0.270 evalue_meat_01 <- multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                    vi = meta_meat$vi,                                    biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                                    selection_ratio = 4,                                    q = 0.1) evalue_meat_01$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   bias_est   bias_ci #>      <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1    0.107 0.0000737 evalue_meat_conf <- multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                      vi = meta_meat$vi,                                      biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                                      selection_ratio = 4,                                      assumed_bias_type = list(EValue::confounding())) evalue_meat_conf$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   bias_est bias_ci evalue_est evalue_ci #>      <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1    0.539   0.270       2.82      1.95

what:
Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and
  Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses
title:
Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and
  Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses
text: multibiasmeta R package provides bias correction sensitivity analysis joint effects within-study across-study biases meta-analysis (per Mathur, 2022).

title:
Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and
  Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses
text: can install multimetabias CRAN: can install development version multibiasmeta GitHub :

title:
Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and
  Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses
text: Calculate meta-analytic effect size estimate, correcting 1) publication bias assumed selection ratio 4 (.e., affirmative results 4x likely published nonaffirmative ones); 2) internal biases assumed mean values (scale yi values). Calculate high mean internal bias need attenuate effect size estimate null, assuming selection ratio 4.
code: library(multibiasmeta) multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi, vi = meta_meat$vi, biased = TRUE, selection_ratio = 4,                bias_affirmative = log(1.5), bias_nonaffirmative = log(1.1)) multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi, vi = meta_meat$vi, selection_ratio = 4,                  biased = !meta_meat$randomized)

title: Meta-analysis about meat consumption — meta_meat
text: Meta-analysis effectiveness educational behavior interventions attempt reduce meat consumption appealing animal welfare.

Meta-analysis about meat consumption — meta_meat
text: data frame 100 rows 4 columns: yi Point estimate log-risk ratio scale vi Variance point estimate cluster Paper contributed point estimate randomized Logical indicating whether study randomized

title: Meta-analysis about meat consumption — meta_meat
text: Mathur MB, Peacock J, Reichling DB, Nadler J, Bain PA, Gardner CD, Robinson TN (2021). “Interventions reduce meat consumption appealing animal welfare: Meta-analysis evidence-based recommendations.” Appetite, 164, 105277.

what: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
text: E-value meta-analysis multiple biases

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
code: multibias_evalue(   yi,   vi,   sei,   cluster = 1:length(yi),   biased = TRUE,   selection_ratio,   q = 0,   favor_positive = TRUE,   alpha_select = 0.05,   ci_level = 0.95,   small = TRUE,   bias_max = 20,   assumed_bias_type = NULL )

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
text: yi vector point estimates meta-analyzed. vi vector estimated variances (.e., squared standard errors) point estimates. sei vector estimated standard errors point estimates. (one vi sei needs specified). cluster Vector length number rows data, indicating cluster study considered part (defaults treating studies independent; .e., study cluster). biased Boolean indicating whether study considered internally biased; either single value used studies vector length number rows data (defaults studies). selection_ratio Ratio publication bias favors affirmative studies (.e., studies p-values less alpha_select estimates direction indicated favor_positive). q attenuated value shift point estimate CI. specified scale yi (e.g., yi log-RR scale, q well). favor_positive TRUE publication bias assumed favor significant positive estimates; FALSE assumed favor significant negative estimates. alpha_select Alpha level estimate's probability favored publication bias assumed change (.e., threshold study investigators, journal editors, etc., consider estimate significant). ci_level Confidence interval level (proportion) corrected point estimate. (alpha level inference corrected point estimate calculated ci_level.) small inference allow small meta-analysis? recommend always using TRUE. bias_max largest value bias, additive scale, included grid search. bias units yi. assumed_bias_type List biases consider computing evalues (objects bias returned EValue::confounding(), EValue::selection(), EValue::misclassification()) (defaults NULL, .e. agnostic nature internal bias). NULL, yi argument must log-RR scale (yi already scale, use EValue::convert_measures() make ).

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
text: object class metabias::metabias(), list containing: data tibble one row per study columns yi, vi, sei, cluster, biased. values list elements selection_ratio, q, favor_positive, alpha_select, ci_level, small, bias_max. stats tibble columns bias_est, bias_ci, evalue_est, evalue_ci.

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
text: functions passed assumed_bias_type, see EValue package multiple-bias vignette: vignette("multiple-bias", package = "EValue")

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
text: Mathur MB (2022). “Sensitivity analysis interactive effects internal bias publication bias meta-analyses.” doi:10.31219/osf.io/u7vcb . Ding P, VanderWeele TJ (2016). “Sensitivity analysis without assumptions.” Epidemiology (Cambridge, Mass.), 27(3), 368. Smith LH, VanderWeele TJ (2019). “Bounding bias due selection.” Epidemiology (Cambridge, Mass.), 30(4), 509. VanderWeele TJ, Li Y (2019). “Simple sensitivity analysis differential measurement error.” American journal epidemiology, 188(10), 1823--1829.

title: E-value for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_evalue
code: # specify confounding as internal bias evalues <- multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi,                             vi = meta_meat$vi,                             biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                             selection_ratio = 4) evalues$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   bias_est bias_ci #>      <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1    0.539   0.270  # specify confounding as internal bias evalues_confounding <- multibias_evalue(yi = meta_meat$yi,                                         vi = meta_meat$vi,                                         biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                                         selection_ratio = 4,                                         assumed_bias_type = list(EValue::confounding())) evalues_confounding$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   bias_est bias_ci evalue_est evalue_ci #>      <dbl>   <dbl>      <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1    0.539   0.270       2.82      1.95

what: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
text: Correction meta-analysis multiple biases

title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
code: multibias_meta(   yi,   vi,   sei,   cluster = 1:length(yi),   biased = TRUE,   selection_ratio,   bias_affirmative,   bias_nonaffirmative,   favor_positive = TRUE,   alpha_select = 0.05,   ci_level = 0.95,   small = TRUE,   return_worst_meta = FALSE,   return_pubbias_meta = FALSE )

title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
text: yi vector point estimates meta-analyzed. vi vector estimated variances (.e., squared standard errors) point estimates. sei vector estimated standard errors point estimates. (one vi sei needs specified). cluster Vector length number rows data, indicating cluster study considered part (defaults treating studies independent; .e., study cluster). biased Boolean indicating whether study considered internally biased; either single value used studies vector length number rows data (defaults studies). selection_ratio Ratio publication bias favors affirmative studies (.e., studies p-values less alpha_select estimates direction indicated favor_positive). bias_affirmative Mean internal bias, additive scale, among published affirmative studies. bias units yi. bias_nonaffirmative Mean internal bias, additive scale, among published nonaffirmative studies. bias units yi. favor_positive TRUE publication bias assumed favor significant positive estimates; FALSE assumed favor significant negative estimates. alpha_select Alpha level estimate's probability favored publication bias assumed change (.e., threshold study investigators, journal editors, etc., consider estimate significant). ci_level Confidence interval level (proportion) corrected point estimate. (alpha level inference corrected point estimate calculated ci_level.) small inference allow small meta-analysis? recommend always using TRUE. return_worst_meta Boolean indicating whether worst-case meta-analysis nonaffirmative studies returned. return_pubbias_meta Boolean indicating whether meta-analysis correcting publication confounding returned.

title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
text: object class metabias::metabias(), list containing: data tibble one row per study columns yi, vi, sei, biased, cluster, affirmative, yi_adj, weight, userweight. values list elements selection_ratio, bias_affirmative, bias_nonaffirmative, favor_positive, alpha_select, ci_level, small. stats tibble columns model, estimate, se, ci_lower, ci_upper, p_value. fit list fitted models.

title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
text: Mathur MB (2022). “Sensitivity analysis interactive effects internal bias publication bias meta-analyses.” doi:10.31219/osf.io/u7vcb .

title: Correction for meta-analysis with multiple biases — multibias_meta
code: # publication bias without internal bias meta_0 <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                          vi = meta_meat$vi,                          selection_ratio = 4,                          bias_affirmative = 0,                          bias_nonaffirmative = 0) meta_0$stats #>       model  estimate         se   ci_lower  ci_upper      p_value #> 1 multibias 0.1293691 0.02103083 0.08711307 0.1716251 1.335523e-07  # publication bias and internal bias in the non-randomized studies meta_4 <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                          vi = meta_meat$vi,                          biased = !meta_meat$randomized,                          selection_ratio = 4,                          bias_affirmative = log(1.5),                          bias_nonaffirmative = log(1.1)) meta_4$stats #>       model   estimate         se   ci_lower  ci_upper      p_value #> 1 multibias 0.09491905 0.02405073 0.04662505 0.1432131 0.0002453537  # treat all studies as biased, not just non-randomized ones meta_all <- multibias_meta(yi = meta_meat$yi,                            vi = meta_meat$vi,                            biased = TRUE,                            selection_ratio = 4,                            bias_affirmative = log(1.5),                            bias_nonaffirmative = log(1.1)) meta_all$stats #>       model   estimate         se    ci_lower  ci_upper   p_value #> 1 multibias 0.01020086 0.02103083 -0.03205518 0.0524569 0.6297933

what: multibiasmeta: Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses — multibiasmeta-package
title: multibiasmeta: Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses — multibiasmeta-package
text: Meta-analyses can compromised studies' internal biases (e.g., confounding nonrandomized studies) well publication bias. package conducts sensitivity analyses joint effects biases (per Mathur, 2022 [doi:10.31219/osf.io/u7vcb ]). sensitivity analyses address two questions: (1) given severity internal bias across studies publication bias, much results change?; (2) given severity publication bias, severe internal bias , hypothetically, attenuate results null given amount?

title: multibiasmeta: Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses — multibiasmeta-package
text: Mathur MB (2022). “Sensitivity analysis interactive effects internal bias publication bias meta-analyses.” doi:10.31219/osf.io/u7vcb . Ding P, VanderWeele TJ (2016). “Sensitivity analysis without assumptions.” Epidemiology (Cambridge, Mass.), 27(3), 368. Smith LH, VanderWeele TJ (2019). “Bounding bias due selection.” Epidemiology (Cambridge, Mass.), 30(4), 509. VanderWeele TJ, Li Y (2019). “Simple sensitivity analysis differential measurement error.” American journal epidemiology, 188(10), 1823--1829. Mathur MB, Peacock J, Reichling DB, Nadler J, Bain PA, Gardner CD, Robinson TN (2021). “Interventions reduce meat consumption appealing animal welfare: Meta-analysis evidence-based recommendations.” Appetite, 164, 105277.

title: multibiasmeta: Sensitivity Analysis for the Interactive Effects of Internal Bias and Publication Bias in Meta-Analyses — multibiasmeta-package
